citations.narrative:
In the food storage area bags of bird food were observed being stored directly on the ground and against the wall with
yard equipment placed on top of two bags. Storing food supplies away from the walls and off the ground helps prevent
contamination and spoilage, while supporting efficient cleaning for all supplies stored. Supplies of food, food supplements,
bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects against deterioration, spoilage, contamination, and
vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and
around the supplies. All food must be stored in a manner that prevents deterioration of its nutritive value.
Corrected at time of inspection May 6, 2025.

Sharp points were observed in three macaw enclosures housing two birds each. The sharp points consisted of broken or
bent wires that were protruding into the enclosures and were located next to the feeder doors and in the corners of the
enclosures. In addition, at least two enclosures housing two Derbyan parakeets each had holes created to allow the birds
access to a plastic PCV pipe with drinking attachments. The PCV pipe was not attached to the enclosure and was easily
dislodged leaving sharp wire points protruding into the enclosure and a hole in the enclosure wall posing a potential risk
for entrapment. Sharp points or edges from broken or unmaintained materials in birds' enclosures may cause injury to the
birds. Primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and maintained so that they do not have any sharp points or edges
that could injure the birds.
Correction Date June 6, 2025.

The primary enclosure housing five cranes does not provide an aquatic area for swimming and/or wading. The lack of an
aquatic area for aquatic birds does not allow the birds to make normal postural and social adjustments and can lead to
poor condition, debility, stress, and or abnormal behavioral patterns. Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic
birds must contain a pool or other aquatic areas (e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water features) and a dry
area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Both the aquatic and dry areas must be of
sufficient size to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement
and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure.
Corrected at time of inspection May 6, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the Crane enclosure housing five birds, the water receptacle had a moderate to heavy accumulation of dirt, debris, and
algae growth along the sides and bottom of the receptacle and the water was not clear. Water receptacles should be
maintained in a manner to minimize contamination to ensure the health and well-being of the animals. Failure to sanitize
food and water receptacles can increase disease hazards, insects, odors, and pests. Food and water receptacles must be
sanitized as often as necessary to prevent accumulations of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards.
In the dove enclosure housing 15 doves, there was a tall mound of excreta, approximately 6 inches wide and 10 inches
tall beneath a perch. The facility representative stated the enclosure had not been cleaned in 2 – 3 days. Insufficient
cleaning and sanitization of primary enclosures for birds can result in poor air quality, attract pests, cause odors, and play
a role in disease transmission. The licensee must ensure that excreta is removed from primary enclosures and from under
and around primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and to reduce disease
hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
Corrected a time of inspection on April 30, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Areas around the bird enclosures are cluttered with items that do not promote good housekeeping practices. There are at
least 3 areas within the bird housing area where discarded cages and caging material have been stacked. There is tall
grass and weeds intertwined within these cages as well as tall grass and weeds in at least three bird enclosures. There is
a mild accumulation of cobwebs present in a maintenance room and in the corners within the indoor bird housing area.
Accumulations of discarded items and tall grass and weeds can attract rodents and other pests to animal areas. Dirt and
debris can collect in cobwebs, increasing disease hazards in animal areas. Premises must be kept free of accumulation of
trash, junk, waste products, and discarded matter. Weeds, grasses, and bushes must be controlled so as to facilitate
cleaning of the premises and pest control to protect the health and well-being of the birds.
Correction Date June 6, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.150(e) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the food storage area bags of bird food were observed being stored directly on the ground and against the wall with 
yard equipment placed on top of two bags. Storing food supplies away from the walls and off the ground helps prevent 
contamination and spoilage, while supporting efficient cleaning for all supplies stored. Supplies of food, food supplements,

Corrected at time of inspection May 6, 2025. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Sharp points were observed in three macaw enclosures housing two birds each. The sharp points consisted of broken or 
bent wires that were protruding into the enclosures and were located next to the feeder doors and in the corners of the

dislodged leaving sharp wire points protruding into the enclosure and a hole in the enclosure wall posing a potential risk 
for entrapment. Sharp points or edges from broken or unmaintained materials in birds' enclosures may cause injury to the 
birds. Primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and maintained so that they do not have any sharp points or edges 
that could injure the birds.  
 
Correction Date June 6, 2025. 
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary enclosure housing five cranes does not provide an aquatic area for swimming and/or wading. The lack of an 
aquatic area for aquatic birds does not allow the birds to make normal postural and social adjustments and can lead to 
poor condition, debility, stress, and or abnormal behavioral patterns. Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic

birds must contain a pool or other aquatic areas (e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water features) and a dry

sufficient size to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement 
and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. 
 
Corrected at time of inspection May 6, 2025. 
3.158(b)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
In the Crane enclosure housing five birds, the water receptacle had a moderate to heavy accumulation of dirt, debris, and 
algae growth along the sides and bottom of the receptacle and the water was not clear. Water receptacles should be

food and water receptacles can increase disease hazards, insects, odors, and pests. Food and water receptacles must be

In the dove enclosure housing 15 doves, there was a tall mound of excreta, approximately 6 inches wide and 10 inches

cleaning and sanitization of primary enclosures for birds can result in poor air quality, attract pests, cause odors, and play

and around primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and to reduce disease 
hazards, insects, pests, and odors. 
 
Corrected a time of inspection on April 30, 2025. 
3.158(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Areas around the bird enclosures are cluttered with items that do not promote good housekeeping practices. There are at 
least 3 areas within the bird housing area where discarded cages and caging material have been stacked. There is tall 
grass and weeds intertwined within these cages as well as tall grass and weeds in at least three bird enclosures. There is

Accumulations of discarded items and tall grass and weeds can attract rodents and other pests to animal areas. Dirt and

Correction Date June 6, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: CONGO AFRICAN GREY PARROT / GRAY PARROT

species.common: DOMESTIC PIGEON INCLUDING ALL DOMESTIC BREEDS
